p.p: Use this rule to ensure that a given primitive value is lower than or equal to a given specified value.

A corresponding "maximum" rule exists for the following Java primitive types - and their object representation:
TypeRule
int or java.lang.IntegermaxInt
long or java.lang.LongmaxLong
float or java.lang.FloatmaxFloat
double or java.lang.DoublemaxDouble

sapia:sect-desc.p:
Specifies the name of the accessor whose return value must be a Java primitive, or the object representation of a Java primitive. The rule ensures that the validated value is lower than or equal to the one specified by the "value" attribute - see next.
If the object to validate is a null reference, an error is generated.
If this attribute is omitted, the current object on the validation context's stack will be validated - and cast to the expected type. This attribute's value must use the property access notation specified by the BeanUtils libary - see the library's javadoc for more information.
A primitive value corresponding to the expected maximum.

sapia:code.content:
<vlad xmlns:vlad="http://www.sapia-oss.org/vlad/rules">
<ruleSet id="customerCredit">
<vlad:maxFloat attribute="customer.credit" value="1000.00"> <message value="You are limited to purchases of $1000 or less."/> </vlad:maxFloat>
</ruleSet> </vlad>
